repnme.cdata!:
Easing Armenia's transition to a
            market economy

abstracts.cdata!:
With independence in 1991, Armenia
            suffered a severe economic contraction. Between 1990 and
            1993, GDP dropped by more than 50 percent. This led to
            hyperinflation, a budget deficit that reached a high of 55
            percent, factory closures, little electricity supply, and
            large-scale emigration. About 80 percent of the population
            survived on humanitarian assistance and more than half the
            population lived below the poverty line.

docna.cdata!: Transicion de Armenia hacia una economia de mercado

display_title.display_title:
Easing Armenia's transition
            to a market economy : Transicion de Armenia hacia una
            economia de mercado

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Fifth Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial, with satisfactory ratings for both the
            Bank and Borrower performances. Notwithstanding, lessons
            suggest the following. The establishment of macroeconomic
            fundamentals before focusing on improving the business
            environment is an effective development strategy. The
            overall strategy of the reform program under the initial
            Rehabilitation Credit Project through this Fifth Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project proved successful, i.e.,
            macroeconomic fundamentals were first established, to then
            focus on improving the business environment. With rapid
            growth and fiscal savings through social sector
            rationalization, higher social expenditures were possible
            simultaneously, with continued business environment
            improvements. Thus, the social sectors could also be
            adequately funded. Moreover, monitoring instruments and
            taking into account feedbacks can play an important role in
            design and implementation of an effective reform program

docna.cdata!: Armenia - Fifth Structural Adjustment Credit Project

display_title.display_title:
Armenia - Fifth Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Fifth Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project for Armenia's support the Government's
            efforts in: a) developing the private sector and
            accelerating public enterprise reform to facilitate
            sustainable growth and poverty reduction; b) promoting
            public sector reforms to strengthen governance and improve
            efficiency in utilizing existing budgetary resources; and c)
            advancing social sector reforms, including education,
            health, social protection and pension to ensure social
            sustainability of the reform program. The project supports
            the main elements of the Government's reform program
            outlined in the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP), and
            is fully consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy
            (CAS), discussed by the Executive Board of Directors on May
            21, 2002. Additionally, the project will provide foreign
            exchange to support the balance of payments,
            non-inflationary budget financing, and support the
            Government's policy to eliminate barriers for private
            sector development, and advancing social reforms. In
            conclusion, the project will sustain the pace of economic
            recovery and poverty reduction.
